data.title: vscode debug values should take into account source map names
data.body:
The ES5 transpilers such as Typescript and babel translate nested `this` into `_this1`, `this2` e.t.c

the source map generated by transpiler contains what names should be used as the values but this isn't taken into account via inline values or hover in the editor. To get the actual values, a user has to do guess via console on what the generated property is actually called. 

I believe the experience can be improved. Happy to send a PR if you guide me on how to get source map names from the debug adapter.

@roblourens @isidorn

data.title: Focus current symbol when opening symbols list
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: 10.12.1

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Put caret inside a function in a PHP file with many functions.
2. Open symbols list.

Current behavior: Symbols list opens without any symbol selected. Pressing ↓ selects the first symbol in a list.

Wanted behavior: The current symbol is selected. Pressing ↑ or ↓ selected the previous or next symbol in the file. This is how Sublime Text works. Quick way to figure out what function you are in!

data.title: Copy-paste doesn't work properly with Unix-style line endings under Windows

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new file in vscode, set line endings to LF and type some lines of text (pressing enter a few times between each line)
2. CTRL-A, CTRL-C
3. Open putty and ssh into a remote linux box (e.g. ubuntu)
4. Open a text editor on the remote box (e.g. nano) and paste the text - all empty lines are gone

This is because vscode (unlike most other editors on Windows e.g. Sublime) does not convert line endings to the platform's native line ending format when placing text in to the clipboard. As a result other Windows programs (like putty) have problems working with it.

The only workaround (I have found) is to temporarily change the line-endings to CRLF, copy the text and then change them back to LF.  It's cumbersome and error prone.
 
Unsure if this is a vscode issue or an electron one as a similar issue exists with Atom (see: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/8365)

data.title: editor.selectionHighlight set to false not respected in .scss files
data.body: - VSCode Version: Version 1.10.2 (1.10.2) - OS Version: Mac OS 10.12.3 Steps to Reproduce: 1. Set editor.selectionHighlight to false 2. Confirm setting in HTML document 3. Create and .scss document 4. With multiple lines containing same word/selector etc., place cursor inside one iteration. Others highlight. I have editor.selectionHighlight set to false, and in a PHP file it seems to be off. However, in a .scss document, putting my cursor in a selector will highlight all other similar selectors. See attached.

"editor.wrappingColumn": 80 // or "editor.wrappingColumn": 110 

"editor.wordWrap": "off",

data.title: Double clicking a symbol starting/ending a string highlights the adjacent quotes

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
When writing JavaScript, double clicking symbols that start a string highlights both the symbols and the single or double quote to the left of it. If there's a left parenthesis to the left of the quote, that is highlighted too. The reverse happens for symbols ending a string, except the highlight also extends to a line-terminating semicolon if it's to the right of the right parenthesis.

If the first or last word are only letters, the selection is only of the words themselves, as expected.

- VSCode Version: Version 1.10.2 (1.10.2), 8076a19fdcab7e1fc1707952d652f0bb6c6db331
- OS Version: MacOS 10.12.3 (16D32)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enter line: `console.log('### ###');`
2. Double click either the first `###` or the second to observe.
3. Also try `console.log('######');` and `console.log('###abc###');`

Probably related: If the cursor is positioned in one of those leading or trailing string symbols and you use Option-Left/Right to skip to the end of that word at the string boundary, it will also skip over the string quote, parenthesis, and semicolon, unlike if it was letters only.

data.title: language specific editor.wordBasedSuggestions setting doesn't override the global setting
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 1607 14393.693

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new empty folder and open it in VSCode
2. In that folder - create a new xml file 
3. Open workspace settings and set the following settings:
'''{
    "editor.wordBasedSuggestions": true,
    "[xml]": {
        "editor.wordBasedSuggestions": false
    }    
}
'''
4. Open the XML file, type a few words and press Ctrl+Space

Actual result:
Word based suggestions show up
Expected result:
No suggestions showing up

![wordbasedsuggestions](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/23653165/23961603/b7799866-09ab-11e7-98d0-81878fc72ef9.png)

data.title: Pop-up Hints showing incorrect JSDoc description or no description for variables/constants referencing a function
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

```javascript

/**
 * description of a
 */
function a() { }

/**
 * description of curry
 */
function curry() { }

/**
 * description of c
 */
var c = a;
const d = curry(a);
```

VSCode started with --disable-extensions

VSCode Version: 1.10.2
OS Version: Microsoft Windows [Version 10.0.14393]

data.title: after i finish 'npm run watch',how can i start vscode.i need help.
Feature request: Select closing bracket, show function/array/etc... opening tag with indent-guide hover-highlight.
data.body:
![example](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11015467/23958188/41a0a3c8-096f-11e7-8bd7-f9bd720a5712.png)


It's probably a bad thing I found the support request for VS code haha.

So I have this problem where when working with very long functions, I click on the closing bracket and I don't know what function that is. So I will hover over the indent guide and scroll up, until I run into the opening bracket to figure out what it is. It might be an object for example. Also applies to `<div>` tags. Anything "out of view" of the coding pane.

Regarding the hover-highlight on the indent guide, that would be a cool feature if you could hover on the indent guides and highlight them (along side with the feature above).

The highlighting part might be redundant/unnecessary if you can show the opening tag name so you don't have to trace by scrolling upwards.

If this has already been addressed, my apologies.

Attached is an image to show the rough functionality.

data.title: PowerShell PSEdit support in Integrated Terminal
data.body: PowerShell ISE has this useful "psedit" command that allows you to open a file to edit through a remote session (http://www.powershellmagazine.com/2014/12/08/pstip-editing-remote-file-in-powershell-ise/).  I prefer working in VSCode, so it would be great if VSCode could support the psedit command in it's Integrated PowerShell Terminal.

data.title: Added an option to disable the mnemonics in the main menu
data.body:
Added an option to disable the mnemonics in the main menu. On Ubuntu, when they are present, they overwrite the bound keys from within the application.

Due to another long standing bug in gnome-related systems (not sure exactly which system is at fault), it is also very difficult to remove this mnemonic behavior at the window manager level, so it seems at the application level is where this has to be disabled currently: 

https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/nautilus/+bug/1113420

Let me know if the setting name & namespace are ok. This is my first contribution to the project, I'm available & willing to amend the PR and fix any faux-pas or oversight :)

data.title: Improved rendering of Seti icons
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2 and 1.11.0 Insider build (b9857a)
- OS Version: Windows 10 Build 14393.693

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Enable vs-seti icon set
2. Create a file with .sh extension (for example)

Icon is simply a grey square; the [Seti icon set for Atom](https://atom.io/packages/seti-icons) suggests there should be some detail displayed.

Here's an enlarged comparison with VSCode on top and the version from the Seti summary below:

![comparison](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22765233/23946498/83e0a050-0972-11e7-99ab-03fcf0e93ee7.png)

And here's a rendering of the original [Seti shell.svg](https://github.com/jesseweed/seti-ui/blob/master/icons/shell.svg) using Inkscape:

![2017-03-15 12_44_45-shell svg - inkscape](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22765233/23949020/698678c8-097d-11e7-9bab-a0a64557d7a1.png)

Loading the seti.woff file (in eval version of FontCreator) shows the icons to be poorly rendered at larger sizes as well, which I assume is due to a problem converting from the SVGs to WOFF?

A selection of the icons as viewed in FontCreator:
![2017-03-15 13_09_54-fontcreator 10 1 unregistered - seti woff - seti](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22765233/23949950/36aed0c2-0981-11e7-820c-d75fcccb47a4.png)

Here's the C# Icon from the WOFF:
![2017-03-15 13_11_04-fontcreator 10 1 unregistered - seti woff - seti](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22765233/23949958/3da1ac38-0981-11e7-958d-c020ffcba5da.png)

And here's the same icon from the original SVG (viewed in Inkscape):
![2017-03-15 13_12_39-c-sharp svg - inkscape](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/22765233/23949967/431fcd3e-0981-11e7-9309-0e24f987830f.png)

data.title: Convert indentation on save
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.10.2
- OS Version: Win 10

It would be nice to add option to automatically change indentation on save.
Something like `"editor.convertIndentationOnSave": true`.

Like this sublime extension : [ExpandTabsOnSave](https://github.com/bubenkoff/ExpandTabsOnSave-SublimeText).

data.title: Restrict Intellisense
data.body:
While using javascript, ~90% of the suggestions I feel are useless. I seem to only use suggestions based on the project (ex: variables, methods, etc...) and snippets. 

Is it anyway to restrict Intellisense to remove the generic suggestions?

I turned off `quickSuggestions` to prevent seeing the tons of suggestions but, I realized I still would like to see the suggestions specific to the open project.

data.title: Recognize altKey correctly on macOS
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.0-insider (6a002910356c6e087dd93e819e4ad54c68b9857a)
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.3

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Define this keybinding and try it: `{"key": "alt+u", "command": "cursorHome"}`

What's expected: For `cursorHome` command to be invoked.
What actually happens: This character gets written: ¨

Atom used to have this problem too, which was solved by this PR: https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/pull/163

More context: https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/13043

data.title: Optionally Run Language Servers/Extensions using Windows Subsystem for Linux
data.body:
Similar to the request for #20220 but more general. Running the Windows version of Code from bash on Windows using WSL works really well. The problem with the set-up is that the language server and extension environment in code is using the Windows environment, but the terminal is using the WSL environment. These are essentially two different operating systems, different executables installed and configured.

It would be better to be able to configure VSCode on Windows to fork all processes using WSL (bash) rather than the native Windows command shell. This applies to language servers and other extensions.

data.title: First cut of theming inside the workbench
Allow snippets to control the scope to which they are applicable
data.body: We know have solid information about the current position/cursor being in a *string*, in a *comment*, in a *regex*, and elsewhere. We should expose this to snippet authors such that their snippets can express where they want to show
